00028 # ^uses $Parser::installed

00030 if (!$Parser::installed) {
00031   die "\n************************************************************\n" .
00032         "* This problem requires the Parser.pm package, which doesn't\n".
00033         "* seem to be installed.  Please contact your WeBWorK system\n".
00034         "* administrator and ask him or her to install it first.\n".
00035         "************************************************************\n\n"
00036 }

00041         "* administrator and ask him or her to install it first.\n".

00048 
00049 =head1 MACROS
00050 
00051 =head1 Formula
00052 
00053     Formula("formula");
00054 
00055 The main way to get a MathObject Formula object (an equation that depends on one
00056 or more variables).
00057 
00058 =cut
00059 
00060 # ^function Formula
00061 # ^uses Value::Package
00062 sub Formula {Value->Package("Formula()")->new(@_)}
00063 
00064 =head2 Compute
00065 
00066     Compute("formula"[, var=>value, ...]);
00067 
00068 Compute the value of a formula and return a MathObject appropriate to its
00069 value.  Set the object so that the correct answer will be shown exatly as in the
00070 given string rather than by its usual stringification.  If the value is a
00071 Formula and any var=>value pairs are specified, then the formula will be
00072 evaluated using the given variable values.  E.g.,
00073 
00074     $x = Compute("x+3",x=>2)
00075 
00076 will produce the equivalent of $x = Real(5).
00077 
00078 The original parsed formula will be saved in the object's original_formula
00079 field, and can be obtained by
00080 
00081     $x->{original_formula};
00082 
00083 if needed later in the problem.
00084 
00085 =cut
00086 
00087 # ^function Compute
00088 # ^uses Formula
00089 sub Compute {
00090   my $string = shift;
00091   my $formula = Formula($string);
00092   $formula = $formula->{tree}->Compute if $formula->{tree}{canCompute};
00093   if (scalar(@_) || $formula->isConstant) {
00094     my $f = $formula;
00095     $formula = $formula->eval(@_);
00096     $formula->{original_formula} = $f;
00097   }
00098   $formula->{correct_ans} = $string;
00099   return $formula;
00100 }
00101 
00102 =head2 Context
00103 
00104     Context();
00105     Context($name);
00106     Context($context);
00107 
00108 Set or get the current context.  When a name is given, the context with that
00109 name is selected as the current context.  When a context reference is provided,
00110 that context is set as the current one.  In all three cases, the current context
00111 (after setting) is returned.
00112 
00113 =cut
00114 
00115 # ^function Context
00116 # ^uses Parser::Context::current
00117 # ^uses %context
00118 sub Context {Parser::Context->current(\%context,@_)}
00119 # ^variable our %context
00120 %context = ();  # Locally defined contexts, including 'current' context
00121 # ^uses Context
00122 Context();      # Initialize context (for persistent mod_perl)
